title: SA is trying to make it easier to do business, but too slowly
text:
Business SA is trying to make it easier to do business, but too slowly

Even though South Africa is taking steps to improve the efficiency and quality of its business regulations, other countries in the world are reforming at a faster pace.

This was one of the highlights in this week’s World Bank Doing Business report, which compared business regulations in 190 economies.

The report showed that economies in sub-Saharan Africa continued to improve their business climates, with the region’s largest economy, Nigeria, earning a place among the year’s top global improvers, alongside Togo.

South Africa’s rank dropped slightly, from 82 for this year to 84 for next year.

The report’s ease of doing business score compared South Africa’s business environment between 2017/18 and 2018/19, whereas the doing business ranking assessed South Africa’s performance in relation to the other 189 economies analysed in the study.



THE GOOD

Inés Zabalbeitia Múgica, a regulatory specialist at the World Bank who worked on the report, said: “South Africa’s rank dropped slightly, but the overall business environment improved in 2018/19.

“The country’s score increased from 66.7 to 67, meaning it became easier for local investors to do business. South Africa is indeed creating better conditions for local business to flourish, but it is reforming slower than other economies.”

Múgica said a reform in the area of enforcing contracts stood in South Africa’s favour – the country improved the quality of its judicial administration by introducing the specialised court dedicated to hearing commercial cases.

“A more sophisticated and streamlined court structure led to an improved business environment in South Africa in the past year,” she said.

South Africa is ranked high (13th) when it comes to safeguarding minority investors. This means that minority investors are well protected from conflicts of interest and that shareholders’ rights in corporate governance are properly guaranteed in South Africa.

THE BAD

South Africa is lagging in the areas of trade facilitation and business incorporation.

“South Africa ranks 145th in trading across borders, and the study points out that Durban port handling charges are relatively expensive compared with neighbouring countries’,” said Múgica.

THE UGLY

One area that desperately needs attention is in the ease of starting a new business, especially due to the country’s high unemployment rate, which jumped to 29% in the second quarter of this year.

“South Africa ranks 139th in starting a business. While it is relatively inexpensive to open a company in South Africa, it still takes up to 40 days for an entrepreneur to start up and formally operate a business. This is almost twice the average in sub-Saharan Africa,” said Múgica.
